sn32.54:1.2.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho so bhikkhu bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn32.54:1.2.eng: Seated to one side, that mendicant said to the Buddha:

sn32.54:1.3.pli: “ko nu kho, bhante, hetu, ko paccayo, yenekadā uṇhaṃ hotī”ti?
sn32.54:1.3.eng: “Sir, what is the cause, what is the reason why sometimes it becomes warm?”

sn32.54:1.4.eng: “Mendicant, there are what are called gods of the warm thunderclouds.

sn32.54:1.6.pli: ‘yannūna mayaṃ sakāya ratiyā vaseyyāmā’ti, tesaṃ taṃ cetopaṇidhimanvāya uṇhaṃ hoti.
sn32.54:1.6.eng: ‘Why don’t we revel in our own kind of enjoyment?’ Then, in accordance with their wish, it becomes warm.

sn32.54:1.7.pli: Ayaṃ kho, bhikkhu, hetu, ayaṃ paccayo, yenekadā uṇhaṃ hotī”ti.
sn32.54:1.7.eng: This is the cause, this is the reason why sometimes it becomes warm.”

sn32.57:1.2.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho so bhikkhu bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn32.57:1.2.eng: Seated to one side, that mendicant said to the Buddha:

sn32.57:1.3.pli: “ko nu kho, bhante, hetu, ko paccayo, yenekadā devo vassatī”ti?
sn32.57:1.3.eng: “Sir, what is the cause, what is the reason why sometimes the heavens rain?”

sn32.57:1.4.eng: “Mendicant, there are what are called gods of the rainy thunderclouds.

sn32.57:1.6.pli: ‘yannūna mayaṃ sakāya ratiyā vaseyyāmā’ti, tesaṃ taṃ cetopaṇidhimanvāya devo vassati.
sn32.57:1.6.eng: ‘Why don’t we revel in our own kind of enjoyment?’ Then, in accordance with their wish, the heavens rain down.
sn32.57:1.6.comm: The “gods” of the rainy thunderclouds are distinct from the “god” (singular) who sends rain. This is lost in translation, as I use the plural form “heavens” in the latter case. It seems the revels of the gods of the rainy clouds induce Indra to send forth rain.

sn32.57:1.7.pli: Ayaṃ kho, bhikkhu, hetu, ayaṃ paccayo, yenekadā devo vassatī”ti.
sn32.57:1.7.eng: This is the cause, this is the reason why sometimes the heavens rain.”

sn33.1:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
sn33.1:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

sn33.1:1.2.pli: Atha kho vacchagotto paribbājako yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodi.
sn33.1:1.2.eng: Then the wanderer Vacchagotta went up to the Buddha and exchanged greetings with him.
sn33.1:1.2.comm: This Saṁyutta can be seen as a supplement to the “Vacchagotta trilogy” (MN 71, MN 72, and MN 73), which depicts Vacchagotta’s growth from a curious skeptic to a realized master; see notes there for details. His verse is at Thag 1.112, and he also features in SN 44.7–11 and AN 3.57.

sn33.1:1.3.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho vacchagotto paribbājako bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn33.1:1.3.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to the Buddha:

sn33.1:1.4.pli: “ko nu kho, bho gotama, hetu, ko paccayo, yānimāni anekavihitāni diṭṭhigatāni loke uppajjanti—
sn33.1:1.4.eng: “What is the cause, worthy Gotama, what is the reason why these various misconceptions arise in the world? That is:

sn33.1:1.5.pli: sassato lokoti vā, asassato lokoti vā, antavā lokoti vā, anantavā lokoti vā, taṃ jīvaṃ taṃ sarīranti vā, aññaṃ jīvaṃ aññaṃ sarīranti vā, hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇāti vā, na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇāti vā, hoti ca na ca hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇāti vā, neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇāti vā”ti?
sn33.1:1.5.eng: the cosmos is eternal, or not eternal, or finite, or infinite; the soul and the body are one and the same, or the soul is one thing, the body another; after death, a realized one still exists, or no longer exists, or both still exists and no longer exists, or neither still exists nor no longer exists.”

sn33.1:1.6.pli: “Rūpe kho, vaccha, aññāṇā, rūpasamudaye aññāṇā, rūpanirodhe aññāṇā, rūpanirodhagāminiyā paṭipadāya aññāṇā;
sn33.1:1.6.eng: “Vaccha, it is because of not knowing form, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation

sn33.1:1.7.eng: that these various misconceptions arise in the world.

sn33.1:1.9.pli: neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇāti vāti.

sn33.1:1.10.pli: Ayaṃ kho, vaccha, hetu, ayaṃ paccayo, yānimāni anekavihitāni diṭṭhigatāni loke uppajjanti—
sn33.1:1.10.eng: This is the cause, this is the reason.”

sn33.1:1.11.pli: sassato lokoti vā, asassato lokoti vā …pe…

sn33.1:1.12.pli: neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇāti vā”ti.

sn33.26-30:0.3.eng: Five Discourses on Not Distinguishing Form, Etc.

sn33.26-30:1.2.pli: “Rūpe kho, vaccha, asallakkhaṇā …pe… viññāṇe kho, vaccha, asallakkhaṇā …pe….
sn33.26-30:1.2.eng: “Vaccha, it is because of not distinguishing form …”
sn33.26-30:1.2.comm: From here to the end of the Saṁyutta, we find a series of terms for “understanding” that do not appear elsewhere in the early canon. It stretches credulity, even by the repetitive standards of the Suttas, that Vacchagotta would have continued asking the same question dozens of times and the Buddha answer only by changing the verb. Likely the redactors introduced these terms, showing the influence of the Abhidhamma on the Saṁyutta.

sn33.6-10:1.11.eng: “… consciousness, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation …”

sn34.1:1.1.comm: The other Jhānasaṁyutta (SN 53.1) focuses on the meditation states, where here we focus on the process of developing and perfecting meditation. The whole is built up as a systematic “wheel” (cakka) of permutations, a form familiar from the Vinaya and Abhidhamma. In such structures, first a set of items is listed, then they are juxtaposed with each other, one pair at a time, until the possibilities are worked out systematically. This cakka serves to systematize similar teachings at AN 2.163, AN 6.24, AN 6.72, AN 7.40, AN 7.41, AN 9.36:10.3, and AN 10.84:2.3.

sn34.1:1.2.comm: “Meditator” is jhāyī, “practitioner of jhāna”. As usual, in this Saṁyutta jhāna and samādhi are synonyms. Various skills in developing refined meditation are itemized.

sn34.1:1.4.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco jhāyī samādhismiṃ samādhikusalo hoti, na samādhismiṃ samāpattikusalo.
sn34.1:1.4.eng: One meditator is skilled in immersion but not in entering it.
sn34.1:1.4.comm: They cannot attain absorption whenever they want (compare DN 15:36.1).

sn34.1:1.5.pli: Idha pana, bhikkhave, ekacco jhāyī samādhismiṃ samāpattikusalo hoti, na samādhismiṃ samādhikusalo.
sn34.1:1.5.eng: One meditator is not skilled in immersion but is skilled in entering it.

sn34.1:1.6.pli: Idha pana, bhikkhave, ekacco jhāyī neva samādhismiṃ samādhikusalo hoti, na ca samādhismiṃ samāpattikusalo.
sn34.1:1.6.eng: One meditator is skilled neither in immersion nor in entering it.

sn34.1:1.7.pli: Idha pana, bhikkhave, ekacco jhāyī samādhismiṃ samādhikusalo ca hoti, samādhismiṃ samāpattikusalo ca.
sn34.1:1.7.eng: One meditator is skilled both in immersion and in entering it.

sn34.1:1.8.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, yvāyaṃ jhāyī samādhismiṃ samādhikusalo ca hoti samādhismiṃ samāpattikusalo ca ayaṃ imesaṃ catunnaṃ jhāyīnaṃ aggo ca seṭṭho ca mokkho ca uttamo ca pavaro ca.
sn34.1:1.8.eng: Of these, the meditator skilled in immersion and in entering it is the foremost, best, chief, highest, and finest of the four.

sn34.1:1.9.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, gavā khīraṃ, khīramhā dadhi, dadhimhā navanītaṃ, navanītamhā sappi, sappimhā sappimaṇḍo tatra aggamakkhāyati;
sn34.1:1.9.eng: From a cow comes milk, from milk comes curds, from curds come butter, from butter comes ghee, and from ghee comes cream of ghee. And the cream of ghee is said to be the best of these.

sn34.1:1.10.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, yvāyaṃ jhāyī samādhismiṃ samādhikusalo ca hoti samādhismiṃ samāpattikusalo ca ayaṃ imesaṃ catunnaṃ jhāyīnaṃ aggo ca seṭṭho ca mokkho ca uttamo ca pavaro cā”ti.
sn34.1:1.10.eng: In the same way, the meditator skilled in immersion and entering it is the foremost, best, leading, highest, and finest of the four.”

sn34.10:1.4.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco jhāyī samādhismiṃ samādhikusalo hoti, na samādhismiṃ sappāyakārī.
sn34.10:1.4.eng: One meditator is skilled in immersion but not in doing what’s conducive to it. …”
sn34.10:1.4.comm: They do things that are unsuitable, distracting the mind (MN 105:25.8, MN 105:18.5.

sn34.10:1.5.pli: Idha pana, bhikkhave, ekacco jhāyī samādhismiṃ sappāyakārī hoti, na samādhismiṃ samādhikusalo.

sn34.10:1.6.pli: Idha pana, bhikkhave, ekacco jhāyī neva samādhismiṃ samādhikusalo hoti, na ca samādhismiṃ sappāyakārī.

sn34.10:1.7.pli: Idha pana, bhikkhave, ekacco jhāyī samādhismiṃ samādhikusalo ca hoti, samādhismiṃ sappāyakārī ca.

sn34.10:1.8.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, yvāyaṃ jhāyī samādhismiṃ samādhikusalo ca hoti samādhismiṃ sappāyakārī ca ayaṃ imesaṃ catunnaṃ jhāyīnaṃ aggo ca seṭṭho ca mokkho ca uttamo ca pavaro ca.

sn34.11:1.4.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco jhāyī samādhismiṃ samāpattikusalo hoti, na samādhismiṃ ṭhitikusalo.
sn34.11:1.4.eng: One meditator is skilled in entering immersion but not in remaining in it. …”
sn34.11:1.4.comm: Now the wheel of permutations starts. The qualities of the first two discourses—entering and remaining—are juxtaposed.

sn34.11:1.5.pli: Idha pana, bhikkhave, ekacco jhāyī samādhismiṃ ṭhitikusalo hoti, na samādhismiṃ samāpattikusalo.

sn34.11:1.6.pli: Idha pana, bhikkhave, ekacco jhāyī neva samādhismiṃ samāpattikusalo hoti, na ca samādhismiṃ ṭhitikusalo.

sn34.11:1.7.pli: Idha pana, bhikkhave, ekacco jhāyī samādhismiṃ samāpattikusalo ca hoti, samādhismiṃ ṭhitikusalo ca.

sn34.11:1.8.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, yvāyaṃ jhāyī samādhismiṃ samāpattikusalo ca hoti, samādhismiṃ ṭhitikusalo ca ayaṃ imesaṃ catunnaṃ jhāyīnaṃ aggo ca seṭṭho ca mokkho ca uttamo ca pavaro ca.

sn34.12:1.4.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco jhāyī samādhismiṃ samāpattikusalo hoti, na samādhismiṃ vuṭṭhānakusalo.
sn34.12:1.4.eng: One meditator is skilled in entering immersion but not in emerging from it. …”

sn34.12:1.5.pli: Idha pana, bhikkhave, ekacco jhāyī samādhismiṃ vuṭṭhānakusalo hoti, na samādhismiṃ samāpattikusalo.

sn34.12:1.6.pli: Idha pana, bhikkhave, ekacco jhāyī neva samādhismiṃ samāpattikusalo hoti, na ca samādhismiṃ vuṭṭhānakusalo.

sn34.12:1.7.pli: Idha pana, bhikkhave, ekacco jhāyī samādhismiṃ samāpattikusalo ca hoti, samādhismiṃ vuṭṭhānakusalo ca.
